explanation:
For determining whether the memcpy call in MHD_add_connection (&addrstorage, addr, (size_t) addrlen) can access beyond the bounds of the destination or source, the analyser must know the exact sizes/semantics and conditional behavior that affect the copy length:

- struct sockaddr_storage (definition / sizeof(...)) — memcpy writes into an object of this type (addrstorage). To check for overflow we must know its compile-time size.

- struct sockaddr (definition: sa_family, sa_len members) — the function reads addr->sa_family and (conditionally) addr->sa_len. The presence, type and meaning of sa_len influence whether addrlen is constrained before the memcpy.

- struct sockaddr_in (definition / sizeof(...)) — the code checks sizeof(struct sockaddr_in) against addrlen for AF_INET. The concrete size is required to determine if those checks prevent unsafe copies.

- struct sockaddr_in6 (definition / sizeof(...)) — similarly required for the AF_INET6 checks when HAVE_INET6 is defined.

- HAVE_STRUCT_SOCKADDR_SA_LEN (configuration macro) — when defined the code uses addr->sa_len and later may reduce addrlen to addr->sa_len. Whether this macro is defined changes the control flow and the effective value of addrlen passed to memcpy.

- HAVE_STRUCT_SOCKADDR_STORAGE_SS_LEN (configuration macro) — determines whether addrstorage.ss_len is assigned. While this does not directly bound the memcpy, it is part of the sockaddr_storage layout/usage on platforms where ss_len exists and may affect correct size assumptions.

- HAVE_INET6 (configuration macro) — if undefined the IPv6 branch (and its checks) is omitted; knowing whether it is defined is necessary to understand which checks are present before memcpy.

- AF_INET and AF_INET6 (macro/constant values) — the code compares addr->sa_family to these constants to decide which size checks to perform; the analyzer needs these symbols to reason about which branch applies.

- memcpy (from <string.h>) — the rule under analysis targets standard string.h functions; include memcpy to reason about its semantics (it copies exactly the given number of bytes and does not check bounds).

- socklen_t (definition / range/representation) — addrlen is of this type; its width and signedness may affect integer comparisons and conversions (e.g., when compared to sizeof(...) which yields size_t) so the precise type is needed to ensure comparisons and casts cannot produce unintended large values passed to memcpy.

Providing these symbols (definitions/macros) lets the next analyser determine whether every possible path into MHD_add_connection ensures addrlen is never greater than sizeof(addrstorage) and that the source object 'addr' is large enough for the requested copy length, thereby checking compliance with the MISRA string.h bounds rule.
